'Pseudouridine' (abbreviated by the Greek letter psi- Î¨) is the C-glycoside
isomer of the nucleoside uridine, and it is the most prevalent of the over one
hundred different modified nucleosides found in RNA. Î¨ is found in
all species and in many classes of RNA except mRNA. Î¨ is
formed by enzymes called Î¨ synthases, which post-transcriptionally isomerize
specific uridine residues in RNA in a process termed
pseudouridylation.

It is commonly found in tRNA, associated with thymidine and cytosine in the TÎ¨C
arm and is one of the invariant regions of tRNA.The function of it is not very
clear, but it is expected to play a role in association with aminoacyl
transferases during their interaction with tRNA, and hence in the initiation of
translation. Recent studies suggest it may offer protection from
radiation.
